H0.text: Releasing thermal energy in irregular spurts is how a change in the pattern of warm ocean currents can cause a climate change.

H1.text: Absorbing thermal energy from the Sun's rays is how a change in the pattern of warm ocean currents can cause a climate change.

H2.text: Moving thermal energy from one place to another is how a change in the pattern of warm ocean currents can cause a climate change.

H3.text: Increasing the ocean's capacity for absorbing thermal energy is the effect of a change in the pattern of warm ocean currents that can cause climate change.

A4.text: Ocean currents influence the temperature of the regions through which they travel. For example, warm currents traveling along more temperate coasts increase the temperature of the area by warming the sea breezes that blow over them.

A5.text: There is evidence that surface warming due to anthropogenic climate change has accelerated upper ocean currents in 77% of the global ocean.
